results.title: Neighbours (the remix) - Destiny Deacon (Over d-Fence)
results.brief_description: A half-hour program that references the global success of the soap-opera Neighbours. Consisting of three nine-minute segments by an emerging documentarian, an emerging fiction moving image maker, and by a visual artist, Neighbours (the remix) will playfully subvert and imaginatively redraw the landscape of Australia suburbia. As part of Neighbours (the remix) there will be interspersed ad-breaks (30 second duration each) by five leading, established art practitioners.

results.title: Neighbours (the remix) - David Jolly (Siesta)
results.brief_description:
Too hot to sleep I took a walk during siesta through two Barcelona suburbs, Pedralbes and Les Corts. Adjacent to each other only in location.
I wandered through the tree lined streets and deserted apartment blocks, ‘pry to close (a tip from a local) and they’ll escort you out of there’. The only signs of humanity amongst the empty sound of sprinklers were the pool cleaners, gardeners and maids, quietly maintaining an order.
A contrast to the jubilant cries of children playing after school, rushing through the sun filled holes knee down on skateboards, playing soccer on a concrete field defined by its long shadows cast by the superstructures of high density public housing, their home.

results.title: Neighbours (the remix) - DAMP (Full potato jacket)
results.brief_description: The scene is familiar. A scene you know well. A buffet setting of multinational brands adorns a beautifully set table. Products which for years you have been told you want; you need. The camera pans the table. You recognise everything. So what happens when the desirable turns undesirable? Melbourne art collective DAMP wage war on themselves in a gluttonous, misappropriation of food. A food fight of excessive proportions aims to subvert the subliminal desire global advertising has imposed, via mass media, on mainstream Australia.

results.title: Neighbours (the remix) - Cherine Fahd (Touch: a family portrait)
results.brief_description:
The 30-second moving image for the Neighbours project is titled Touch ‘ A Family Portrait. It is a portrayal of a family greeting each other on Christmas Eve. The 30-second edit concentrates on the family’s overwhelming display of affection towards each other, their intense ‘kissing’ and ‘touching’. The camera/edits jump from one person to the next, as they kiss from cheek to cheek and affectionately embrace, whilst all speaking at once.

It portrays a multi-racial (Lebanese, Australian, American) family whose affection is displayed and celebrated and whose cultural identity exists beyond the stereotypes of multiculturalism. This piece functions as an antidote or as a somewhat more realistic alternative to the tokenistic portrayal of non-Anglo Australians, in television productions such as ‘Neighbours’.

results.title: Neighbours (the remix) - Brook Andrew (Hail Amerika)
results.brief_description: The new work for Neighbours (the remix) is obvious in nature. It repeats American logo. In Australia, I find my life pervaded by Amerikanism. My art practice comments on Amerikanisation within Australian and the world culture and mediums, so with all the current world domination attitudes by Amerika, it pops up again. This time like a resounding hammer bashing down hard on the little people who have no power but to listen and bob heads, ‘yes…I do’. Fear is translated through our determination to buy McDonalds and waver in American soapies, news and perspectives.

results.title: The Clerk
results.creator_credit: Allan Wargon, Morten Parker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Nature of Work”.
This film explores the conflict between what a man (in this case an office clerk) wants from his job and what the company wants from him. It raises the question of how far an industry ought to be expected to go in relieving dull, repetitive work for the sake of employee satisfaction.

results.title: The Vice President
results.creator_credit: Hugh O'Connor, Morten Parker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Nature of Work”.
Elevation to the position of Vice-President brings prestige responsibility and freedoms of action, but it also means a shifting of loyalties and the losing of personal contact. This is shown in the dramatised story of John Harvard who rising from Branch Director to Vice-President finds himself having to put pressure on the men who a short time ago were his near equals. Only by going against their wishes can he serve the best interests of his company.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hugh O’Connor, Morten Parker and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Skilled worker
results.creator_credit: Morten Parker, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Nature of Work”.
This film examines the inroads of automation on whole areas of satisfaction and reward in work, as exemplified in the story of a craftsman who finds his carefully acquired manual skills displaced by a machine. (Award: Stockholm)
